subject: Re: [junit] Question about junit test
msgSnippet: A very old saying from Kent Beck is: Test everything that could possibly break If there is functionality inside the catch-block that needs to work correctly
messageBody:
A very old saying from Kent Beck is: Test everything that could possibly break

If there is functionality inside the catch-block that needs to work
correctly and that could be wrong, then you should write tests for
that. If the catch block does nothing but return null, then testing
with a wrong XPath and expecting null would probably be enough.

Greetings,
Malte


On 24 August 2010 11:17, tcdmail <tcdmail@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I'm pretty new to JUnit testing and I'm having a question regarding writing a test for the example class beneath which e.g. use XPath to query an xml file and returns an object if it's found.
>
> Assume i have the following class
>
> public Class A
> {
>
>  public Object executeXPath (String filename, String xPath)
>  {
>   Object objectA = null
>   ...
>   try
>    {
>      XPathExpression expr = xpath.compile(xPath); // Send a false xPath string into here (resulint in the exception)
>      ...
>    }
>    catch (XPathExpressionException e)
>    {
>       ....
>    }
>
>    return objectA;
>  }
>
>
> Now I have following questions:
>
> Is it neccesary to write a test for the catch block or is it enough to write a test to check if in such a case the return object is null  ?
>
> If it's necessary to write a test how does this test needs to look ?
>
> Tnx in advance for the feedback.
>
> Regards,
> Tom
>
> }
>
>
>
